author: Faisal GH

text:
Minish Cap was awesome, easily one of the Top 10 best Zeldas.
I enjoyed Spirit Tracks myself but I think I know why.
A.) I'm a sucker for character development, particulary relationships of the romantic or hinted romance type which was over half of Spirit Tracks. They get me every time.
B.) Anything was better than the abomination known as the Temple Of The Ocean King. I didn't hate Phantom Hourglass, but my hate for that one Temple knows no bounds. So Spirit Tracks by comparison was a paradise.

author: Superpika

text: Yeah, but the thing is.. Hard mode would most certainly only mean more/stronger monsters while you deal less and/or take more damage. That really isn't "upping the difficulty". It's just making it more tedious. Having a zelda game actually be more difficult would mean making areas that were actually challenging, monsters that would be tough to deal with and intense boss fights. So just having a difficulty selection probably wouldn't make it a whole lot better.
author: Shilag

text: I do agree. I absolutely love the Oracle series, and their synergy. Minish Cap was an excellent game, the style, gameplay and soundtrack was brilliant. But as you say it was a bit too easy overall, I never really felt tremendously challenged.

author: xOmniCloudx

text: It's now been 8 years since I last loved an original portable Zelda game. It's a shame really, especially since Link's Awakening is my favorite in the series with OoT. Minish Cap was very good, I was surprised with how nicely Capcom handled this series (MC and both Oracle games). It was too easy though, but that's a problem that's been following this series for quite a while.
author: SupraDarky
